By contrast, while effortful processing, (D), describes this person’s intense focus on the puzzle, it does not explain the ability to respond quickly to the boarding announcement. Similarly, divided attention, (B), works best on simple tasks and the question stem uses the word “challenging” to describe the puzzle.
questions.short_reason: Focused on sudoku but heard your flight = COCKTAIL PARTY effect! Important info breaks through selective attention. Think: 'Cocktail party = Catching your cue!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Divided attention is doing two tasks at once - the person was filtering OUT announcements.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Automatic processing doesn't explain the sudden attention shift - it's about low-effort tasks.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Effortful processing explains the focus on the puzzle - not the rapid response to boarding.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Cognition, Consciousness, and Language: Explain why 'Cocktail party phenomenon' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
During which of the following stages does dreaming occur?
I. Stage 3
II. Stage 4
III. REM
questions.explanation: About 75% of dreaming occurs during REM, but dreams occur in all other stages of sleep as well. More bizarre dreams are likely to occur during REM.
questions.short_reason: Dreams occur in ALL stages of sleep! About 75% in REM, but 25% in NREM stages 1-4 too. Think: 'Dreams = During all stages (REM is just most vivid)!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Stage 3 alone doesn't account for all dreaming - dreams occur in other stages too.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Stage 4 alone is incomplete - while dreams occur here, they also occur in other stages.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: REM only is incomplete - REM has 75% of dreams, but NREM stages have the other 25%.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Cognition, Consciousness, and Language: Explain why 'I, II, and III' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A college student strives for excellent grades and hopes to graduate with a better GPA than an older sibling. This type of motivation is considered:
questions.explanation: Due to the competitive nature of the motivation, this is considered extrinsic motivation. Extrinsic motivation is based on external conditions, including perceived reward or fear of punishment. In this case, the reward is beating the sibling. There is no suggestion of an uncomfortable internal state or tension, which is an aspect of drives, eliminating (C) and (D).
questions.short_reason: Competing with sibling = EXTRINSIC motivation! External reward (beating sibling) drives behavior. Think: 'Extrinsic = External competition!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Intrinsic motivation comes from internal satisfaction - not comparing to others.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Primary drives are biological needs (hunger, thirst) - not academic competition.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Secondary drives are learned - but this is about motivation type, not drive classification.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'extrinsic motivation.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: When practicing a recital song at home, a student sounds perfectly in pitch to family and friends. However, when performing at the recital in front of a large audience of peers, strangers, and coaches, the student’s pitch and tone are off, resulting in a poor performance. This second performance is best explained by:
questions.explanation: The Yerkes–Dodson law states that there is an optimal level of arousal necessary to perform. If levels of arousal are too high, poor performance can result. In the case of this student performing at a recital, arousal level is very high as a result of nervousness and anxiety, resulting in a poor performance.
questions.short_reason: Too nervous at recital = poor performance = YERKES-DODSON law! There's an optimal arousal level - too much or too little hurts performance. Think: 'Y-D = Your stress has a sweet spot!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Drive reduction is about reducing internal tension - not about performance under arousal.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Instinct approach says behavior comes from innate patterns - not arousal effects on performance.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Maslow's hierarchy is about need prioritization - not arousal's effect on performance.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'the Yerkes–Dodson law.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Seeking homeostasis to reduce an uncomfortable internal state is associated with which motivational theory?
questions.explanation: Drive reduction theory is the theory that one will act to eliminate uncomfortable internal states known as drives. The body will push toward equilibrium, or homeostasis.
questions.short_reason: Reducing uncomfortable internal state = DRIVE REDUCTION! You act to restore homeostasis. Think: 'Drive = Discomfort that Drives action!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Instinct theory says behaviors are innate - not about reducing internal discomfort.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Arousal theory says we seek optimal stimulation - not specifically about reducing discomfort.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Incentive theory focuses on external rewards pulling behavior - not internal states pushing.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'Drive reduction theory' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: People from cultures around the world can identify which of the following emotions?
questions.explanation: The seven universal emotions are happiness, sadness, contempt, surprise, fear, disgust, and anger.
questions.short_reason: 7 UNIVERSAL emotions: Happy, Sad, Fear, Anger, Surprise, Disgust, Contempt. Apathy, anticipation, excitement = NOT universal! Think: 'HSFA-SDC = universal!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Apathy is NOT a universal emotion - it's not consistently recognized across cultures.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Anticipation is NOT one of the seven universal emotions - not universally expressed/recognized.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Excitement is NOT universal - it's a type of happiness but not a distinct universal emotion.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'Happiness, sadness, and surprise' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Experiencing emotion involves three components, which are:
questions.explanation: The three components of emotion are the physiological (changes in the autonomic nervous system), cognitive (subjective interpretation of an emotion), and behavioral (facial expressions and body language) responses.
questions.short_reason: Three components of emotion: PHYSIOLOGICAL (body), COGNITIVE (thoughts), BEHAVIORAL (expressions). Think: 'PBC = Physical, Brain, Conduct!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Reactionary isn't a standard component - and 'emotional' is circular (component of emotion is emotional).
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Physical/mental overlaps, and 'emotional' is circular - these aren't the three standard components.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 'Emotional' is circular - you can't define emotion as having an emotional component.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'physiological, cognitive, and behavioral.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The statement “I noticed my heart racing and breathing rate increasing when I saw a bear, so I am afraid” corresponds most closely with which theory of emotion?
questions.explanation: Experiencing a physiological reaction to a stimulus and then labeling that response as emotion is in line with the James–Lange theory of emotion. In the statement, seeing the bear is the stimulus, an increase in heart rate and breathing rate is the physiological reaction, and identifying this as fear is the emotion experienced.
questions.short_reason: Physical reaction FIRST, then label the emotion = JAMES-LANGE! 'I'm trembling so I must be afraid.' Think: 'James-Lange = Jitters Lead to Labels!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Schachter-Singer includes cognitive APPRAISAL of the situation, not just noticing body states.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Yerkes-Dodson is about arousal and performance - not the sequence of emotion experience.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Cannon-Bard says physiological and emotional happen SIMULTANEOUSLY - not sequentially.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'James–Lange theory' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which theory of motivation is most significantly informed by Darwin’s theory of evolution?
questions.explanation: According to Darwin’s theory of evolution, all species have instincts that help them survive. The instinct theory of motivation states that people are motivated to act based on instincts that they are programmed to exhibit.
questions.short_reason: INSTINCT theory is based on DARWIN's evolution! Behaviors are innate and help survival. Think: 'Instinct = Inherited through evolution!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Arousal theory is about seeking optimal stimulation - not about evolutionary instincts.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Drive reduction is about internal states and homeostasis - not innate evolutionary patterns.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Incentive theory focuses on external rewards - not evolutionary programming.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'Instinct theory' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Simultaneous processing of conscious emotions and physiological activation is the defining feature of which theory of emotion?
questions.explanation: The Cannon–Bard theory of emotion is based on the premise that conscious feelings and physiological components of emotion are experienced at exactly the same time. In this theory, this combination then leads to action. This is commonly confused with the Schachter–Singer theory, (A), in which nervous system arousal occurs and then is labeled based on the context provided by the environment.
questions.short_reason: Feelings and physiology at the SAME TIME = CANNON-BARD! They happen simultaneously, not sequentially. Think: 'Cannon fires Both at once!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Schachter-Singer involves cognitive labeling AFTER arousal - not simultaneous experience.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: James-Lange says physiology FIRST, then emotion - sequential, not simultaneous.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Incentive theory is about motivation from rewards - not about emotion experience timing.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'Cannon–Bard theory' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: All of the following brain regions are primarily responsible for the experience of emotions EXCEPT the:
questions.explanation: The amygdala, prefrontal cortex, and thalamus all play a role in the experience of emotions. The basal ganglia are involved in smooth movement and are not primarily responsible for the experience of emotions.
questions.short_reason: BASAL GANGLIA = movement, not emotion! Amygdala, prefrontal cortex, and thalamus all process emotions. Think: 'Basal = Body movement, not feelings!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: The amygdala is the emotion center - especially for fear and emotional memory.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: The prefrontal cortex regulates emotions and is involved in emotional decision-making.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: The thalamus relays sensory info including emotional stimuli to appropriate brain areas.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'basal ganglia.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A person with high left frontal lobe activity is most likely experiencing which emotion?
questions.explanation: The left frontal lobe is associated with positive feelings, corresponding with joy and happiness. The right frontal lobe is associated with negative feelings, such as sadness and disgust, (B) and (D).
questions.short_reason: LEFT frontal = positive emotions! Right frontal = negative. Think: 'Left = Laughter, Right = Resentment!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Sadness is associated with RIGHT frontal lobe activity, not left.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Surprise is not strongly lateralized to one side like positive/negative emotions are.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Disgust is a negative emotion - associated with right frontal activity, not left.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'Happiness' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Determination of the intensity and risk of a stressor occurs during which stage(s) of stress appraisal?
questions.explanation: Secondary appraisal of stress is the stage at which the ability of the organism to cope with the stressor is evaluated. This is based on the harm, threat, and challenge of the stressor, which are all correlated with its intensity. Primary appraisal is simply the initial determination of whether there is a negative association at all, not its intensity.
questions.short_reason: SECONDARY appraisal = How do I cope? Can I handle this? What are my resources? Think: 'Secondary = Sizing up your coping ability!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Primary appraisal is just 'Is this a threat or not?' - no intensity evaluation yet.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Intensity is evaluated in secondary, not both - primary is just threat identification.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Intensity IS evaluated - it happens during secondary appraisal of coping ability.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'Secondary appraisal only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A medical student is feeling a high level of stress due to upcoming exams and pressure from family to engage in activities at home. The student chooses to go to the gym for a workout to help relax. This workout is which type of stress?
questions.explanation: A positive stressor creates eustress. Because working out is used to relax, it is considered a eustress. Hassle, (A), and frustration, (B), are both types of distress, (C), or negative stressors.
questions.short_reason: Going to the gym to RELAX = EUSTRESS! Positive stress that benefits you. Exercise is good stress! Think: 'Eustress = Euphoric stress!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Hassles are minor daily annoyances - like traffic, not intentional exercise.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Frustration occurs when goals are blocked - the gym is a chosen activity, not a blocker.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Distress is negative, harmful stress - exercise for relaxation is beneficial.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'Eustress' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which type of conflict is associated with the LEAST amount of stress?
questions.explanation: Approach–approach conflict is one in which both results are good outcomes. While one must be chosen, neither choice results in a negative outcome: for example, choosing between two desserts. Avoidance–escape conflict, (D), is not a recognized form of conflict; these two terms are related to types of negative reinforcers.
questions.short_reason: APPROACH-APPROACH = both options are GOOD! Choosing between two desserts = minimal stress. Think: 'Both approach = Both attractive!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Avoidance-avoidance = choosing between two BAD options - very stressful.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Approach-avoidance = one option with both good and bad aspects - creates ambivalence.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Avoidance-escape isn't a conflict type - these are types of negative reinforcement.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'Approach–approach conflict' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: While cleaning your house, you notice a large spider on the wall by your head and feel your heart rate jump up and your skin temperature grow warm. Which stage of stress response are you experiencing?
questions.explanation: The initial reaction to stress, which is activation of the sympathetic nervous system, is the alarm stage of stress response.
questions.short_reason: Seeing spider + heart racing + getting warm = ALARM stage! Initial fight-or-flight response. Think: 'Alarm = Adrenaline first!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Resistance stage is prolonged coping - you'd need to deal with the spider for a while first.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Exhaustion happens after prolonged stress - not from one spider sighting.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Homeostasis is the baseline state - the spider disrupted it, triggering alarm.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'Alarm' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Each of the following responses to stress is considered maladaptive EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Progressive muscle relaxation is a relaxation technique demonstrated to help reduce stress in a manner that is beneficial to the body and psyche. The other methods described here, including avoidance of the stressor, (D), serve to increase stress or merely change the source of the stress.
questions.short_reason: Progressive muscle relaxation = ADAPTIVE coping! Tensing and relaxing muscles actually reduces stress. Think: 'PMR = Positive, Measured Response!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Drug use is maladaptive - it creates new problems while avoiding the stressor.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Social withdrawal is maladaptive - isolation makes stress worse long-term.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Avoiding stressors is maladaptive - it doesn't address the problem and often backfires.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Motivation, Emotion, and Stress: Explain why 'progressive muscle relaxation.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Each of the following is considered a part of a person’s self-concept EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Self-concept is defined as the sum of all of the ways in which we see ourselves, including who we are, as in (D), who we were in the past, (A), and who we may become in the future, (C). The ought self, while closely related to self-esteem, is our appraisal of how others see us and is not a part of our self-concept.
questions.short_reason: OUGHT self = what others think you SHOULD be. That's not part of your self-CONCEPT (how YOU see yourself). Think: 'Ought = Others' expectations!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Past self IS part of self-concept - who you were shapes how you see yourself now.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Future self IS part of self-concept - who you might become matters to self-perception.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Self-schemata ARE part of self-concept - they're the building blocks of how you see yourself.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'the ought self.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: As a gender identity, androgyny is defined as:
questions.explanation: Androgyny is defined as scoring highly on scales of both femininity and masculinity. Achieving a low score on both scales, (A), would be considered undifferentiated, while (B) and (C) would be described as feminine and masculine, respectively.
questions.short_reason: ANDROGYNY = HIGH on BOTH masculinity AND femininity! Both/and, not either/or. Think: 'Andro (man) + Gyn (woman) = Both high!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Low/low = undifferentiated - neither masculine nor feminine traits are prominent.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: High feminine/low masculine = simply feminine gender identity.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Low feminine/high masculine = simply masculine gender identity.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'high femininity, high masculinity.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A high school student struggles consistently with math and feels that no amount of studying will help because “I just don’t get it.” Which of the following is the most likely short-term result with respect to the student’s ability to do math?
questions.explanation: Because there is nothing in the question stem to suggest that this situation will fundamentally change this student’s attitudes in the short term, (A) and (D) can be eliminated. (C) is unlikely in the short term, as learned helplessness requires a repeated inability to have any effect on a situation over a long period of time and is much more severe, usually manifesting as depression. It is far more likely that the student will simply feel ineffective when it comes to math, which is low self-efficacy.
questions.short_reason: Feeling unable to succeed at ONE task = low SELF-EFFICACY (task-specific confidence). Not helplessness yet - that takes prolonged failure. Think: 'Efficacy = Effectiveness at one thing!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Low self-esteem is global self-worth - one class struggle wouldn't cause this immediately.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Learned helplessness requires prolonged, repeated failure across situations - this is early/localized.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: External locus of control is attributional style - the question is about confidence, not attribution.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'Low self-efficacy' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A district attorney with an internal locus of control wins an important court trial. Which of the following best represents the lawyer’s attribution of the events?

options.A: “I won because I made great arguments and had more experience than the defense.”
options.B: “I won because the jury was on my side from the beginning and believed my arguments.”
options.C: “I won because the defense did not adequately present their side of the case.”
options.D: “I shouldn’t have won because I don’t deserve to be successful.”

questions.explanation: Because we know the lawyer has an internal locus of control, we expect belief in being in control of the events happening in life. Both (B) and (C) attribute success to outside factors, representing an external locus of control. While (D) perhaps represents an attribution that could correlate to low self-esteem, it is not indicative of locus of control.
questions.short_reason: INTERNAL locus = 'I control my success!' The attorney takes PERSONAL credit for winning. Think: 'Internal = I did it!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Crediting the jury = EXTERNAL locus - attributing success to others, not self.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Blaming defense = EXTERNAL locus - attributing success to opponent's failure, not own skill.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: This sounds like low self-esteem or imposter syndrome - not locus of control.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why '“I won because I made great arguments and had more experience than the defense.”' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A person keeps an extremely tidy desk and becomes very nervous whenever things are disorganized or out of place. In which of the following stages would a psychodynamic therapist say this person had become fixated?
questions.explanation: Both excessive organization and excessive sloppiness are indicative of fixation in the anal stage of psychosexual development—what is commonly referred to as anal-retentiveness.
questions.short_reason: Extremely tidy/nervous about disorder = ANAL fixation! Freud said anal-retentive = obsessive orderliness. Think: 'Anal = All about control!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Oral fixation shows as oral habits (smoking, overeating, nail-biting) - not orderliness.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Phallic fixation relates to sexuality/relationships - not cleanliness obsession.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Genital stage is healthy adult sexuality - not characterized by pathological traits.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'The anal stage' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: According to Erikson’s stages of psychosocial development, which of the following would be the most important for a recent college graduate to accomplish?

options.A: Figuring out what identities are most important personally
options.B: Feeling like a contributing member of society
options.C: Forming an intimate relationship with a significant other
options.D: Finding a feeling of accomplishment in life

questions.explanation: As a postadolescent young adult, this person would be described by Erikson as experiencing the conflict of intimacy vs. isolation, and so forming significant relationships with others would be a primary goal. (B) and (D) represent the next two stages in life (generativity vs. stagnation and integrity vs. despair, respectively), while (A) is the conflict that Erikson would say should have been resolved in adolescence (identity vs. role confusion).
questions.short_reason: Recent college grad = INTIMACY vs. isolation stage! Erikson says young adults focus on forming close relationships. Think: 'Intimacy = In your 20s!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Identity vs. role confusion is ADOLESCENCE - should be resolved before college graduation.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Generativity vs. stagnation is middle adulthood - contributing to society/next generation.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Integrity vs. despair is late adulthood - reflecting on life's accomplishments.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'Forming an intimate relationship with a significant other' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Matt and Cati discuss the reasons why they avoid driving above the speed limit. Matt cites wanting to avoid a traffic fine, while Cati says that speeding is dangerous and, if everyone did it, there would be more accidents and people would get hurt. According to Kohlberg, which of the following describes the phases of moral reasoning demonstrated by Matt and Cati, respectively?
questions.explanation: Matt’s reasoning reflects a desire to avoid punishment, which reflects stage one in Kohlberg’s preconventional phase (obedience). Cati’s reasoning takes into account social order, reflecting stage four in the conventional phase (law and order).
questions.short_reason: Speeding = ticket (Matt) vs. speeding = social danger (Cati). Matt = PRECONVENTIONAL (avoid punishment), Cati = CONVENTIONAL (social order). Think: 'Pre = Punishment, Con = Community!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Cati isn't postconventional - she's citing social order (conventional), not universal ethical principles.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: This reverses them - Matt's punishment avoidance is preconventional, not conventional.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Cati isn't postconventional - citing potential accidents is about social order, not abstract ethics.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'Preconventional; conventional' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A child cannot make an origami swan alone, but is able to do so when observing and being assisted by an adult. This scenario is described in the ideas of which of the following theorists?
questions.explanation: This situation is best described by Lev Vygotsky’s zone of proximal development theory, which holds that children are often unable to perform tasks by themselves, but can complete the task with the help of a more knowledgeable other.
questions.short_reason: Can't do alone but CAN with help = VYGOTSKY's Zone of Proximal Development! The 'more knowledgeable other' scaffolds learning. Think: 'Vygotsky = Via mentorship!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Bandura focused on observational learning/modeling - not on assisted task completion.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Adler focused on inferiority complex and striving for superiority - not developmental scaffolding.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Skinner focused on reinforcement/operant conditioning - not on collaborative learning.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'Lev Vygotsky' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a conclusion that can be made from research in role-taking and observational learning?

options.A: Young children will only model actions performed by their parents.
options.B: Celebrities and athletes are an adolescent’s most important role models.
options.C: Children who role-take identities that are not gender typical are more likely to take on those roles later in life.
options.D: A female child is more likely to model the behavior of another female than a male.

questions.explanation: (C) has no support from role-taking research and can be eliminated. (A) and (B) are both inaccurate; the Bobo doll experiment shows young children modeling behavior not performed by their parents, and teens are most influenced by their peers, not celebrities and athletes. The research does suggest, however, that children are more likely to engage in behavior modeled by individuals who are like themselves; thus, a female child is more likely to imitate behavior by another female.
questions.short_reason: Children imitate same-sex models more = observational learning is influenced by MODEL similarity. Think: 'Like imitates like!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Bobo doll experiment showed children imitating STRANGERS - not just parents.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Peers influence teens most - not celebrities (though media figures do have some effect).
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Research doesn't support this conclusion - gender-atypical play doesn't predict later identity.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'A female child is more likely to model the behavior of another female than a male.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A person feels extremely guilty after having an extramarital affair. According to the psychodynamic perspective, which of the following is responsible for this anxiety?
questions.explanation: The superego is responsible for moral guilt when we do not live up to our ideals. While the id and the libido, (A) and (D), may be responsible for the urge to have an affair, the superego is responsible for the anxiety one feels afterward.
questions.short_reason: Guilt after violating values = SUPEREGO! The moral conscience creates guilt when you fail to meet your ideals. Think: 'Superego = Shame generator!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: The id is about pleasure-seeking impulses - it might cause the affair but not the guilt.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: The ego mediates between id and superego - it tries to balance, not generate guilt.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: The libido is sexual energy (id's drive) - it might motivate the affair, not punish for it.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'The superego' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A woman advances through the ranks of a company, eventually becoming the CEO. Which of the following Jungian archetypes reflects this woman’s drive to be successful within the company?
questions.explanation: Jung saw the drive for power and success as typically male traits, so Jung would say this woman is exercising her “inner man.” The animus is the archetype that most closely reflects this quality.
questions.short_reason: Woman striving for power/success = ANIMUS (inner masculine)! Jung said women have an animus archetype representing masculine traits. Think: 'Animus = Ambitious inner man!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Persona is the public mask we show others - not the internal drive for success.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Anima is a man's inner feminine - opposite of what's needed here.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Shadow contains repressed/dark aspects - not positive striving for achievement.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'The animus' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Researchers discover that polymorphisms in the DRD2 gene can be associated with thrill-seeking behavior, and that individuals with certain forms of the gene are more likely to become extreme athletes and have more dangerous hobbies. Which of the following theories is supported by this discovery?
I. The social cognitive perspective
II. The behavioral perspective
III. The biological perspective
questions.explanation: This research supports a link between genetic expression and behavior, which is a central tenet of the biological perspective. The social cognitive perspective also holds that people’s behaviors and traits shape their environments, which in turn have an effect on their identity, so the discovery also supports this perspective. Behaviorism is not supported, as the discovery is not related to rewards and punishments.
questions.short_reason: Genes linked to behavior supports BIOLOGICAL perspective AND social cognitive (traits shape environment). Behaviorism ignores genetics! Think: 'Biology + Social Cog see the gene!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Social cognitive alone is incomplete - biological perspective is also directly supported.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Biological alone misses that social cognitive perspective also fits this finding.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Behaviorism focuses on rewards/punishments, not genetics - it's not supported by this finding.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'I and III only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A person who works as an EMT identifies as a bit of a rebel, but is highly sociable and is able to keep calm in an emergency. This person would likely score in the lower range of which of the following traits?
questions.explanation: As a rebel and a sociable person, this individual would score highly on both psychoticism and extraversion, respectively. Neuroticism is associated with high emotional arousal in stressful situations, so being able to keep calm in an emergency is a sign of low neuroticism. Conscientiousness, a trait associated with being hardworking and organized instead of impulsive, is not described by the question stem.
questions.short_reason: Calm in emergencies = LOW NEUROTICISM! Neuroticism is emotional instability under stress. This EMT keeps cool. Think: 'Neurotic = Nervous under pressure!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Psychoticism includes rebelliousness - the 'bit of a rebel' suggests HIGH psychoticism.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Highly sociable = HIGH extraversion, not low.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Conscientiousness isn't described - we don't know about organization or work ethic.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'Neuroticism' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Stockholm syndrome is a phenomenon in which people who are kidnapped or held hostage may begin to identify with or even feel affection for their captors. A psychoanalyst might explain Stockholm syndrome by citing which of the following defense mechanisms?
questions.explanation: Reaction formation is a defense mechanism that converts unwanted feelings into their exact opposite. A psychodynamic theorist would say that the terror and hatred victims feel toward their captors might be unconsciously turned into affection in an effort to reduce the stress of the situation.
questions.short_reason: Terror transformed into affection = REACTION FORMATION! Converting unwanted feelings into their OPPOSITE. Think: 'Reaction = Reverse the feeling!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Regression is reverting to childish behavior - not changing the emotional content.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Projection is attributing your feelings to others - not transforming them within yourself.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Displacement redirects feelings to a safer target - not reversing their valence.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'Reaction formation' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Having struggled for years through an economic recession, a young professional begins to buy lottery tickets every Friday. “If I won the lottery,” the individual reasons, “I’d finally have the life I’ve always wanted. All my stress would go away and I could live comfortably.” These thoughts regarding winning the lottery are most representative of:
questions.explanation: Fictional finalism is comprised of internal, idealistic beliefs about the future. The assumption that winning the lottery will solve all of life’s problems is representative of this form of thinking. Cardinal traits, (A), are the traits around which individuals organize their entire life. Functional autonomy, (C), is when a behavior continues after the drive behind the behavior has ceased; for example, if this young professional continued purchasing lottery tickets after winning simply for enjoyment, then this behavior would have gained functional autonomy. Unconditional positive regard, (D), is used in some forms of humanistic therapy in which the therapist believes in the internal good of the client and does not judge the client negatively for any words or actions.
questions.short_reason: Winning lottery will solve everything = FICTIONAL FINALISM! Adler's term for idealistic beliefs about future outcomes. Think: 'Fictional = Fantasy future!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Cardinal traits are dominant life-organizing traits (Allport) - not specific beliefs about future.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Functional autonomy is behavior continuing after original motive ends - not future-oriented fantasies.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Unconditional positive regard is Rogers' therapy concept - not about client beliefs.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Identity and Personality: Explain why 'fictional finalism.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a negative symptom seen in schizophrenia?
questions.explanation: Negative symptoms are the absence of normal or desired behavior, which include disturbance of affect and avolition. Positive symptoms are the addition of abnormal behavior, including hallucinations, (A), disorganized behavior, (B), and delusions, (D).
questions.short_reason: Disturbance of affect = ABSENCE of normal emotion = NEGATIVE symptom! Negative = something is taken away. Think: 'Negative = Missing normal behavior!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Hallucinations are ADDED abnormal experiences = positive symptom.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Disorganized behavior is ADDED abnormal behavior = positive symptom.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Delusions are ADDED false beliefs = positive symptom.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'Disturbance of affect' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: During an interview with a schizophrenic patient, a psychiatrist notices that the patient keeps repeating what the psychiatrist says. This phenomenon is known as:
questions.explanation: Echolalia is an involuntary repetition of others’ words and utterances and may be seen in schizophrenia. Echopraxia, (B), is imitation of others’ actions. Loosening of associations, (C), is a type of disordered thought in which the patient moves between remotely related ideas. Neologisms, (D), are newly invented words.
questions.short_reason: Repeating others' WORDS = ECHOLALIA! Echo + lalia (speech). Think: 'Echo-LALIA = Echo-LANGUAGE!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Echopraxia is imitating MOVEMENTS/actions, not words.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Loosening of associations is jumping between loosely related ideas in speech.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Neologisms are inventing NEW words, not repeating others' words.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'echolalia.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A 42-year-old patient has always been extremely neat and tidy. This person works as a secretary and stays long after normal working hours to check the punctuation and spelling of letters prepared during the day. The patient was referred for counseling by a supervisor after repeatedly getting into fights with coworkers. “They don’t take the job to heart,” the patient says. “They just joke around all day.” The most likely preliminary diagnosis for this patient is:
questions.explanation: Focusing on details, loving routine, having a sense that there is only one right way to do things, and lack of humor suggests an obsessive–compulsive personality disorder.
questions.short_reason: Obsessively organized + no humor + rigid rules = OCPD (Obsessive-Compulsive PERSONALITY Disorder)! Different from OCD. Think: 'OCPD = Order, Control, Perfectionism, Disagreeable!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Antisocial PD involves disregard for others' rights, law-breaking - not orderliness.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Narcissistic PD involves grandiosity and need for admiration - not perfectionism about tasks.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Borderline PD involves emotional instability and relationship issues - not rigid orderliness.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'obsessive–compulsive personality disorder.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true with regard to a major depressive episode?

options.A: It may last less than two weeks.
options.B: It must involve thoughts of suicide or a suicide attempt.
options.C: It may involve a decrease in sleep.
options.D: It must involve feelings of sadness.

questions.explanation: Depression is marked by a period of at least two weeks in which the patient has five of nine cardinal symptoms, one of which must be depressed mood or lack of interest (anhedonia). While decreased need for sleep is commonly seen in manic episodes, it may also appear in depression, as sleep disturbance is one of the nine cardinal symptoms. Not all depressed individuals are suicidal, as in (B). In older individuals, depression may often manifest as anhedonia without feelings of sadness, invalidating (D).
questions.short_reason: Sleep disturbance in depression can mean LESS sleep too! Insomnia is common in depression, not just oversleeping. Think: 'Depression disrupts sleep both ways!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Depression MUST last at least 2 weeks - less than 2 weeks doesn't meet criteria.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Suicidal thoughts are one possible symptom, not a requirement for diagnosis.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Anhedonia (loss of interest) can occur WITHOUT sadness - especially in older adults.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'It may involve a decrease in sleep.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A young person moves to a new city to start work on an accelerated degree program. After a few months this individual visits the doctor complaining of stress and isolation and is diagnosed with depression. The doctor ascribes the cause to low levels of serotonin and prescribes an SSRI for treatment. Which of the following best describes the physician’s approach to diagnosis and treatment?
questions.explanation: The doctor is using the biomedical approach since the focus is on only the biological cause of the patient’s symptoms. Furthermore, since the treatment centers only on the patient, the doctor is using direct therapy. This combination of approach and therapy matches (B) as the correct answer. By contrast, a doctor using the biopsychosocial approach would likely consider the patient’s recent move, stresses associated with the accelerated program, and lack of support structure as potential causes of depression. Additionally, treatment using the biopsychosocial approach includes indirect therapy which focuses on increasing social support.
questions.short_reason: Only focused on low serotonin, only treats patient = BIOMEDICAL approach with DIRECT therapy! No social/psychological factors considered. Think: 'Bio = Biology only, Direct = Patient only!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Indirect therapy involves changing the patient's environment/support system - not just medication.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Biopsychosocial would consider the move, stress, and isolation - not just neurochemistry.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Biopsychosocial with direct is contradictory - biopsychosocial inherently includes indirect factors.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'Biomedical approach with direct therapy' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A young person of unknown age is brought by the Philadelphia police to the local emergency department for evaluation after being found wandering in a park. The patient carries no identification and is unable to provide a first or last name or any life details, except that the name Phoenix seems familiar. The police in Arizona are contacted and find a missing persons report matching the patient’s description. Based on this information, the most likely diagnosis for this patient is:
questions.explanation: Dissociative fugue is characterized by sudden travel or change in normal day-to-day activities and occurs in some cases of dissociative amnesia. Symptoms include an inability to recall one’s past or confusion about one’s identity. Thus, the described patient is most likely to be suffering dissociative amnesia accompanied by dissociative fugue.
questions.short_reason: Can't remember identity + traveled far away = Dissociative AMNESIA with FUGUE! Fugue = fleeing with memory loss. Think: 'Fugue = Fleeing + Forgetting!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Depersonalization/derealization is feeling unreal, not losing identity and traveling.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: DID involves multiple personalities - the patient has no personalities, not multiple.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Somatic symptom disorder involves physical symptoms, not memory/identity loss.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'dissociative amnesia with dissociative fugue.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: In addition to being a freestanding diagnosis, agoraphobia is most often seen in association with which other psychiatric diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Agoraphobia, or a fear of places or situations in which it would be difficult to escape, is commonly seen in panic disorder. Concern about having a panic attack in public may make these individuals fearful of leaving their home.
questions.short_reason: Agoraphobia (fear of places you can't escape) often comes WITH panic disorder - fear of having panic attacks in public. Think: 'Agoraphobia = Afraid of panic in public!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: OCD involves obsessions/compulsions - not specifically fear of public places.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Avoidant PD involves social inhibition - but agoraphobia is about escape, not social judgment.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: GAD is pervasive worry - not specifically fear of places where escape is difficult.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'Panic disorder' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A researcher is interested in studying fear responses to a variety of different stimuli. To rule out potential confounding variables, the research excludes individuals with phobias from the study. In a sample of 50 participants, how many will likely be excluded from the study, assuming that the sample is representative of the overall population?
questions.explanation: Phobias affect approximately 9% of the population, meaning that on average 9 in 100 individuals will have some sort of phobia. In a sample of 50 people, 4 or 5 people will need to be excluded, assuming that the sample is representative of the larger population. Thus, (D) is correct.
questions.short_reason: Phobias affect ~9% of population. 9% of 50 = ~4.5 people, so about 5. Think: 'Almost 1 in 10 has a phobia!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 45 out of 50 would be 90% - phobias are common but not THAT common.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 15 out of 50 would be 30% - overestimates phobia prevalence.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 10 out of 50 would be 20% - still overestimates the ~9% prevalence.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why '5' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What two disorders could these symptoms indicate?
questions.explanation: The symptoms listed indicate a major depressive episode. However, depressive episodes can be a part of bipolar disorders, which also contain manic episodes. Thus, if manic episodes have not yet been asked about, one cannot distinguish between depression or bipolar disorder as the correct diagnosis yet.
questions.short_reason: Depressive episode symptoms appear in BOTH major depression AND bipolar disorders! Can't distinguish without asking about mania. Think: 'Depression appears in both - need to check for mania!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Amnesia isn't a distinguishing feature between depression and bipolar disorder.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Phobias are anxiety disorders - not relevant to depression vs. bipolar distinction.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Task difficulty relates to dementia, not depression vs. bipolar differential.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'Major depressive and bipolar disorders' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What should the physician ask about to distinguish between the two possible disorders affecting that patient?

options.B: Whether the patient has also had manic episodes
options.C: Whether the patient is irrationally afraid of anything
options.D: Whether the patient has experienced difficulty performing familiar tasks

questions.explanation: To determine if this patient has major depressive disorder or a bipolar disorder, the presence of manic (or hypomanic) episodes should be confirmed. Bipolar disorders contain manic (or hypomanic) episodes, while major depressive disorder does not.
questions.short_reason: To distinguish depression from bipolar, ask about MANIC episodes! Bipolar = depression + mania (or hypomania). Think: 'Manic history makes it bipolar!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Amnesia isn't relevant to distinguishing depression from bipolar disorder.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Phobias are anxiety symptoms - not distinguishing features for mood disorders.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Difficulty with tasks is more relevant to cognitive disorders like dementia.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'Whether the patient has also had manic episodes' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: All of the following are risk factors or diagnostic criteria for Alzheimer’s disease EXCEPT:

options.A: Extra copies of the β-amyloid precursor protein gene.
options.B: Decreased abundance of serotonin and norepinephrine.
options.C: Neurofibrillary tangles of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.
options.D: Deficient blood flow to the parietal lobes.

questions.explanation: The correct answer should be a statement that is not relevant to Alzheimer’s disease. Choice (B), a decreased abundance of serotonin and norepinephrine, describes the monoamine theory of depression. These neurochemical changes are not known risk factors or diagnostic criteria for Alzheimer’s disease, making (B) the correct answer. The remaining choices are either risk factors or diagnostic criteria for Alzheimer’s disease. Choice (A) describes the increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease in individuals with Down syndrome, as the gene for β-amyloid precursor is on chromosome 21. Choices (C) and (D) both describe biological markers of Alzheimer’s disease.
questions.short_reason: Decreased serotonin/norepinephrine = DEPRESSION theory, not Alzheimer's! Alzheimer's involves amyloid plaques, tau tangles, and brain blood flow issues. Think: 'Monoamines = Mood, not Memory!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Extra beta-amyloid precursor gene copies (Down syndrome) DO increase Alzheimer's risk.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Tau protein tangles ARE a hallmark of Alzheimer's pathology.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Reduced blood flow to parietal lobes IS seen in Alzheimer's disease.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'Decreased abundance of serotonin and norepinephrine.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Splitting is a defense mechanism commonly seen with which personality disorder?
questions.explanation: Splitting, the consideration of others as either “all good” or “all bad,” is characteristic of borderline personality disorder.
questions.short_reason: SPLITTING (all good or all bad) = BORDERLINE PD! Black-and-white thinking about others is a borderline hallmark. Think: 'Borderline = Binary thinking!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Antisocial PD involves disregard for others - not idealization/devaluation patterns.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Histrionic PD involves attention-seeking and drama - not splitting.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Narcissistic PD involves grandiosity - not the all-good/all-bad pattern.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'Borderline personality disorder' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A patient comes to the doctor with a two-week history of complete paralysis of the left arm. The patient has had no injury to the extremity, and full neurological workup fails to demonstrate any underlying cause. The patient seems surprisingly unconcerned about the paralysis, and seems more worried about an argument that happened one month ago in which the patient hit a family member. Based on this information, the patient’s most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Conversion disorder is marked by a motor or sensory symptom in the absence of an underlying physical or neurological cause. It is associated with an inciting event that, in this case, may have been the argument with the family member. The patient’s lack of concern over the deficit is referred to as la belle indifférence.
questions.short_reason: Paralysis with no medical cause + indifference + stressful event = CONVERSION disorder! La belle indifference (calm about symptoms) is a classic sign. Think: 'Conversion = Conflict Converts to body symptoms!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: GAD is pervasive worry - the patient shows indifference, not anxiety.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Illness anxiety is excessive worry about having illness - not actual physical symptoms.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Histrionic PD is attention-seeking personality - not about physical symptom conversion.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'conversion disorder.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A patient is taken to the doctor after starting to move the fingers in such a way that it looks like rolling something, despite nothing actually being there. The patient also exhibits slowed movement and a shuffling gait. Which neurotransmitter is likely to be present in decreased levels in the patient’s brain?
questions.explanation: The symptoms indicate that the patient likely has Parkinson’s disease. This disease is caused by decreased dopamine production in the substantia nigra.
questions.short_reason: Pill-rolling tremor + shuffling gait + slow movement = PARKINSON'S disease! Low DOPAMINE in substantia nigra. Think: 'Parkinson's = Poor Dopamine!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Epinephrine isn't the primary neurotransmitter deficit in Parkinson's.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Histamine isn't related to Parkinson's motor symptoms.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Serotonin is more related to mood disorders - not movement disorders.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'Dopamine' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following is/are true regarding bipolar disorders?
I. They have little, if any, genetic heritability.
II. They are associated with increased levels of serotonin in the brain.
III. They all require at least one depressive episode for diagnosis.
questions.explanation: Bipolar disorders have been shown to be highly heritable and are associated with increased levels of norepinephrine and serotonin in the brain. Bipolar I disorder can be diagnosed with a single manic episode and does not require a major depressive episode. Bipolar II disorder requires at least one hypomanic episode and one major depressive episode. Cyclothymic disorder contains at least one hypomanic episode and dysthymia.
questions.short_reason: Bipolar = HIGH serotonin, HIGH norepinephrine! And Bipolar I only needs mania - NO depression required for diagnosis. Think: 'Bipolar = Boosted neurotransmitters!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Bipolar is HIGHLY heritable (~80%) - statement I is false.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: I is wrong (highly heritable) and III is wrong (Bipolar I doesn't require depression).
wrong_answer_explanations.D: III is wrong - Bipolar I only requires one manic episode, no depression needed.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Psychological Disorders: Explain why 'II only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
The behavior of the individuals in the Stanford prison experiment is best explained by which of the following terms?
I. Bystander effect
II. Deindividuation
III. Internalization
IV. Social loafing
questions.explanation: When fulfilling particular roles, an individual’s behavior can be very out of character. The changing of one’s behavior (and internal ideas) to match a group is called internalization conformity. This was a key part of the experiment. The experiment also involved deindividuation, the loss of self-identity in the group setting that can lead to antinormative or violent behavior.
questions.short_reason: Stanford prison = guards/prisoners internalized roles + lost individual identity = INTERNALIZATION + DEINDIVIDUATION! Think: 'They became their roles and lost themselves!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Bystander effect is about NOT helping when others are present - not relevant to the prison experiment.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Internalization alone is incomplete - deindividuation also explains the extreme behavior.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Social loafing is reduced effort in groups - the opposite of what happened (increased aggression).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'II and III only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A jury member who initially feels that a strict penalty should be placed on the defendant votes for an even stricter penalty after deliberation with the other jury members. This behavior is best described by which social phenomenon?
questions.explanation: The fact that individual opinions became more extreme during group discussion is explained by group polarization. The jury member initially felt that a strict penalty should be given, but this opinion became more extreme after conversation with the rest of the group.
questions.short_reason: Started strict, became STRICTER after group discussion = GROUP POLARIZATION! Groups push opinions to extremes. Think: 'Groups = Going to extremes!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Social facilitation is about improved performance when observed - not opinion change.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Assimilation is absorbing into a culture - not about opinion polarization.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Socialization is learning social norms - not about group discussion effects.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'Group polarization' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following would decrease the likelihood of a bystander lending aid to a victim?

options.A: Increasing the number of people in the room
options.B: Increasing the degree of danger experienced by the victim
options.C: Making the victim an acquaintance instead of a stranger
options.D: Being alone in the room with the victim

questions.explanation: It has been observed that increasing the number of bystanders decreases the likelihood that any of them will aid a victim. Increasing the degree of danger experienced by the victim, (B), making the victim an acquaintance instead of a stranger, (C), and being alone in the room with the victim, (D), would increase the likelihood that the bystander would help the victim.
questions.short_reason: MORE people = LESS likely to help = BYSTANDER EFFECT! Diffusion of responsibility. Think: 'More bystanders = Less action!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: More danger actually INCREASES likelihood of helping.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Knowing the victim INCREASES likelihood of helping.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Being alone INCREASES likelihood of helping (no diffusion of responsibility).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'Increasing the number of people in the room' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: During groupthink, members of the group do all of the following EXCEPT:

options.A: stereotype members outside of the group.
options.C: ignore warnings against the ideas of the group.
options.D: create a sense of negativity against risk taking.

questions.explanation: With groupthink, a member would perform all of the actions described by the answer choices except create a sense of negativity against risk taking; in fact, there is optimism and encouragement toward risk taking in groupthink.
questions.short_reason: Groupthink creates OPTIMISM about risk, not negativity! Groups feel invulnerable and take bigger risks together. Think: 'Groupthink = Gung-ho about risk!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Stereotyping outsiders IS a characteristic of groupthink - in-group vs. out-group.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Self-censorship IS part of groupthink - people don't voice disagreement.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Ignoring warnings IS part of groupthink - warnings are dismissed as unnecessary.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'create a sense of negativity against risk taking.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Adult prison systems may attempt to change the behavior of inmates through all of the following mechanisms of socialization EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Primary socialization is the teaching of acceptable actions and attitudes during childhood, which would occur too early to be part of the adult prison system. Resocialization, (D), is the process by which one changes behaviors by discarding old routines and patterns and transitions to new behaviors necessary for a life change. The prison environment is designed to change unlawful behavior into desired behavior, making this an incorrect choice. When entering prison, an inmate must also undergo secondary socialization, (B), learning the rules of the specific social environment of the prison. Finally, if the inmate is not incarcerated for life, attempts at anticipatory socialization, (C), must be made before releasing the inmate in preparation for life outside of the prison.
questions.short_reason: PRIMARY socialization = childhood learning of basic norms. Adult prison can't do this! They use resocialization, secondary, and anticipatory. Think: 'Primary = Preschool, not Prison!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Secondary socialization teaches prison-specific norms and rules - prisons do this.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Anticipatory socialization prepares inmates for release - prisons attempt this.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Resocialization changes behavior by replacing old patterns - the main goal of rehabilitation.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'primary socialization.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Your neighbors ask you to collect their mail while they are out of town and you agree. Later that day, they ask you to water their plants as well. What technique for compliance are they using in this scenario?
questions.explanation: This is a prime example of the foot-in-the-door technique. The neighbors first ask for a small favor and, after receiving commitment, ask for a larger favor.
questions.short_reason: Small favor first, then bigger favor = FOOT-IN-THE-DOOR! Get a yes, then escalate. Think: 'Foot in door = First small, then big!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Lowball is agreeing to something, then learning it costs more - not escalating requests.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: That's-not-all adds extras before you decide - 'But wait, there's more!'
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Door-in-the-face starts with HUGE request, then reduces - opposite pattern.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'Foot-in-the-door technique' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements represents the affective component of an attitude?

options.B: “I’m going to see a new action movie at the theater.”
options.C: “Action movies are much better than comedies.”
options.D: “Tomorrow, I’m going to rent an action movie.”

questions.explanation: The affective component of attitude consists of feelings and emotions toward something.
questions.short_reason: 'I LOVE action movies' = AFFECTIVE (feeling)! Emotions and feelings = affective component of attitude. Think: 'Affective = Affect = Feelings!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Going to see a movie is BEHAVIORAL - taking action.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Comparing genres is COGNITIVE - thoughts and beliefs about movies.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Planning to rent is BEHAVIORAL - intended action.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why '“I love action movies.”' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: After sitting in a lecture, determining that a professor is a bad teacher based on the professor’s unprofessional attire and monotone speech is an example of which type of processing?
questions.explanation: Peripheral route processing deals with processing information that is not based on content, but instead on superficial parameters such as boring speech patterns or appearance of the speaker. Central route processing, (C), is the processing of information through analysis of its content.
questions.short_reason: Judging by appearance and speaking style = PERIPHERAL route! Surface features, not content. Think: 'Peripheral = Presentation, not points!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Knowledge route isn't a real term in the elaboration likelihood model.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Adaptive route isn't a standard term in persuasion research.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Central route processing focuses on argument CONTENT and logic - not appearance.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'Peripheral route processing' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: In the Milgram shock experiment, many subjects were willing to give the maximal voltage shock because they were influenced by which psychological principle?
questions.explanation: The Milgram shock experiment showed that individuals would obey orders from authority figures even if they were not comfortable with the task at hand. Conformity and compliance, (C) and (D), also deal with changes in individual behavior, but are not based on the requests of an authority figure.
questions.short_reason: Following orders from authority figure = OBEDIENCE! Milgram showed people obey authority even against their values. Think: 'Obedience = Orders from authority!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Deviance is violating social norms - the subjects were following authority.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Conformity is matching peer behavior - not following an authority figure.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Compliance is agreeing to a direct request - less about authority hierarchy.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'Obedience' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Each individual in a group of teenagers is asked to estimate the height of a tree. One individual estimates the height to be 25 feet, but after discussing with the group is convinced that the height is likely closer to 40 feet. Which type of conformity is seen here?
questions.explanation: Internalization refers to the type of conformity in which individuals change their outward opinion to match the group and also personally agree with those ideas.
questions.short_reason: Changed opinion AND personally believes it = INTERNALIZATION! The change is genuine, not just public. Think: 'Internalization = Inner change!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Normative conformity is changing behavior to fit in - but not truly believing it.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Identification is conforming to be like someone you admire - not about genuine belief change.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Compliance is agreeing publicly without private acceptance - opposite of internalization.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'Internalization' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the functional attitudes theory?
questions.explanation: The four functional areas of the functional attitudes theory are knowledge, adaptability, ego expression, and ego defense. Acceptance into a group may influence attitudes or opinions; however, this is not a part of the functional attitudes theory.
questions.short_reason: Functional attitudes theory: Knowledge, Adaptability, Ego expression, Ego defense. No 'Acceptance' - that's not one of the four! Think: 'KAEE = Keep Attitudes Ego-Enhanced!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Knowledge IS one of the four functions - attitudes help us understand the world.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Ego defense IS one of the four functions - attitudes protect self-esteem.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Ego expression IS one of the four functions - attitudes express values.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'Acceptance' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The swimming times for all members of a swim team are tracked over a six-month period in team-only practices and at public meets. For 14 of the 16 members, top times were clocked at the meets. What social phenomenon does this evidence support?
questions.explanation: For 14 out of the 16 members, the record times were obtained during public meets. The fact that the team members performed better when in front of a crowd supports the notion of social facilitation.
questions.short_reason: Swimming faster in front of a crowd = SOCIAL FACILITATION! Performance improves when being watched on well-learned tasks. Think: 'Facilitation = Fans help performance!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Peer pressure implies the group is pushing behavior - but they performed better independently.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Identification is conforming to be like someone - not about performance improvement.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Group polarization is about opinions becoming extreme - not about physical performance.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'Social facilitation' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: An 18-year-old is completing the final months of high school and begins to wake up early each day to run five miles in preparation for joining the Army. What type of socialization is this young person experiencing?
questions.explanation: This young person is preparing to spend time in a new social setting. The process of preparing for future changes in environment is considered anticipatory socialization.
questions.short_reason: Preparing for Army life BEFORE joining = ANTICIPATORY socialization! Learning norms before entering the group. Think: 'Anticipatory = Ahead of time!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Normative socialization isn't a standard term - anticipatory is the correct one.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Informative socialization isn't a standard term in sociology.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Resocialization occurs AFTER entering a new environment - not before.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'Anticipatory socialization' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following best reflects the difference between social action and social interaction?

options.A: Social action refers to positive changes one makes in their society; social interaction refers to the route by which these changes occur.
options.B: Social action refers to the effects of a group on an individual’s behavior; social interaction refers to the effects that multiple individuals all have on each other.
options.C: Social action refers to changes in behavior caused by internal factors; social interaction refers to changes in behavior caused by external factors.
options.D: Social action refers to changes in behaviors that benefit only the individual; social interaction refers to changes in behavior that benefit others.

questions.explanation: Social action is best described as the effects that a group has on individual behavior, including social facilitation, deindividuation, the bystander effect, social loafing, and peer pressure. Social interaction describes how two or more individuals influence each other’s behavior, including group polarization and groupthink.
questions.short_reason: Social ACTION = group effects on individual. Social INTERACTION = individuals affecting EACH OTHER. Think: 'Action = One direction, Interaction = Both ways!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Neither term specifically refers to 'positive changes' or how they occur.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Internal vs. external factors isn't the distinction between these terms.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Individual vs. group benefit isn't the core distinction either.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'Social action refers to the effects of a group on an individual’s behavior; social interaction refers to the effects that multiple individuals all have on each other.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: In the group setting, the mentality of “If you aren’t with us, you’re against us” is most representative of which factor of groupthink?
questions.explanation: Placing spoken or unspoken expectations on individuals to agree with the ideas of the group is best described as pressure for conformity.
