questions.short_reason: 'With us or against us' = PRESSURE FOR CONFORMITY! Forcing agreement or labeling as enemy. Think: 'Pressure = Push to conform!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Illusion of invulnerability is believing the group can't fail - not about forcing agreement.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Illusion of morality is believing the group is inherently ethical - not about pressure.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Self-censorship is individuals voluntarily staying quiet - not active pressure from the group.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Processes, Attitudes, and Behavior: Explain why 'Pressure for conformity' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes the sociological definition of a status?

options.A: The emotional state of a social interaction
options.B: Expectations that are associated with a specific title in society
options.C: A position in society used to classify an individual
options.D: A means to describe one’s peers

questions.explanation: A status is a position in society used to classify a person and exists in relation to other statuses. The specific behaviors associated with this status, (B), best describe a role.
questions.short_reason: STATUS = position in society that classifies you (doctor, parent, student). Role = the expectations that come WITH that status. Think: 'Status = Station in society!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Emotional state is mood/feelings - not sociological status.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Expectations for a title describe ROLE, not status - status is the position itself.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Describing peers would be about group membership, not individual status.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'A position in society used to classify an individual' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Becoming a college graduate requires hard work and diligence in academics. As such, being a college graduate could be considered a(n):
questions.explanation: An achieved status is one that is acquired through personal efforts. This is in contrast to an ascribed status, (A), in which the status is involuntarily given based on race, ethnicity, gender, family background, and so on. A master status, (C), is one that influences all aspects of an individual’s life. While being a college graduate is an important aspect of day-to-day life, it does not usually pervade every part of one’s life.
questions.short_reason: College degree through effort = ACHIEVED status! You earned it through hard work. Think: 'Achieved = Accomplished through effort!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Ascribed status is given at birth (race, gender, family) - not earned through effort.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Master status dominates all others (like 'convict') - college grad usually isn't this defining.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Cardinal status isn't a sociological term - 'cardinal trait' is from psychology.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'achieved status.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A bureaucracy is a specific example of a(n):
questions.explanation: A bureaucracy is an example of an organization, specifically one with the goal of performing complex tasks as efficiently as possible. Immediate networks and primary groups, (A) and (B), are characterized by strong, intimate bonds, which are not commonly seen in bureaucracies. Reference groups, (D), are those groups to which we compare ourselves for various characteristics.
questions.short_reason: Bureaucracy = formal ORGANIZATION designed for efficiency. It's a type of organization with hierarchy and rules. Think: 'Bureaucracy = Big organization!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Immediate networks are close personal connections - bureaucracies are impersonal.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Primary groups have strong bonds - bureaucracies are secondary/formal structures.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Reference groups are those we compare ourselves to - not formal work structures.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'organization.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT characteristic of a bureaucracy?

options.B: Requirement for officials to hold an advanced degree

questions.explanation: Generally, bureaucracies are marked by six characteristics: paid officials on a fixed salary; nonelected officials who are provided rights and privileges as a result of making their career out of holding office; regular salary increases, seniority rights, and promotions upon passing exams or milestones, (C); officials who enter the organization by holding an advanced degree or training, (B); responsibilities, obligations, privileges, and work procedures rigidly defined by the organization, (A); and responsibility for meeting the obligations of the office one holds.
questions.short_reason: Bureaucracies have APPOINTED officials, not ELECTED ones! Election isn't a bureaucratic characteristic. Think: 'Bureaucrats = Hired, not elected!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Rigid procedures ARE a bureaucratic characteristic - standardization is key.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Requirement for credentials/degrees IS a bureaucratic feature.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Regular salary increases based on seniority IS a bureaucratic characteristic.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'Election by constituents' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a form of verbal communication?
questions.explanation: Verbal communication uses words (whether spoken, written, or signed). Nonverbal communication uses other means of signaling emotions or ideas, such as body language, (D), facial expressions, (A), eye contact, (B), prosody, and personal space. Hand gestures and other bodily movements are also often nonverbal communication, but can be verbal when used as part of a sign language.
questions.short_reason: Written text uses WORDS = VERBAL communication! Verbal doesn't mean only spoken - it means using words. Think: 'Verbal = Words (written or spoken)!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Facial expressions are nonverbal communication - no words involved.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Eye contact is nonverbal - it communicates without words.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Body language is nonverbal - posture and gestures aren't words.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'Written text' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes the impression management strategy of aligning actions?

options.A: Adhering to the behaviors that are expected for a given role in society
options.B: Relieving tension brought about by holding conflicting views in one’s head
options.C: Providing socially acceptable reasons to explain unexpected behavior
options.D: Dictating that members of a group should follow similar practices to one another

questions.explanation: Aligning actions is an impression management technique in which one provides socially acceptable reasons for unexpected behavior. This may manifest as providing an excuse for poor performance or laughing off an inappropriate comment as a joke. Tension created from having conflicting thoughts or opinions, as mentioned in (B), refers to cognitive dissonance.
questions.short_reason: Giving excuses for unexpected behavior = ALIGNING ACTIONS! Making your actions align with social expectations through explanation. Think: 'Aligning = Explaining away!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Following expected behaviors is role performance - not explaining unexpected behavior.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Cognitive dissonance is internal conflict - not explaining behavior to others.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Group conformity is about following others - not individual behavior management.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'Providing socially acceptable reasons to explain unexpected behavior' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: While on the phone, a friend says: “A good friend would let me borrow the bike.” This friend is using which impression management strategy?
questions.explanation: Imposing a role on another person (in this case, “good friend”) is the hallmark of alter-casting. This example is also the opposite of ingratiation, (C), because the implication behind the statement is that not lending the bike makes one a “bad friend”; ingratiation is the use of flattery or conformity to win over someone else.
questions.short_reason: 'A good friend would...' = ALTER-CASTING! Forcing a role (good friend) onto someone to get compliance. Think: 'Alter-cast = Assign a role!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Managing appearances is about how YOU look - not assigning roles to others.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Ingratiation is flattery to gain favor - this is more like manipulation.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Self-disclosure is revealing personal information - not role assignment.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'Alter-casting' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a Gesellschaft ?

options.D: An ethnic enclave in a large city

questions.explanation: A Gesellschaft (society) is one in which individuals are working toward the same goal, such as a company or country. Gemeinschaften (communities), on the other hand, are those that are bonded together by beliefs, ancestry, or geography.
questions.short_reason: Large corporation = GESELLSCHAFT (society)! People united by common GOAL (profit), not bonds. Think: 'Gesellschaft = Goal-oriented group!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Rural neighborhood is Gemeinschaft - bonded by location and tradition.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Family is Gemeinschaft - bonded by kinship and shared history.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Ethnic enclave is Gemeinschaft - bonded by shared heritage and culture.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'A large corporation' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: In some cultures, it is considered taboo for one to show too much sadness at a funeral. In other cultures, wailing and crying loudly is expected. These cultures differ in their:
questions.explanation: Display rules are those that dictate cultural expectations of emotion. In some cultures, sadness is considered personal and internal; in others, sadness is shared externally with the community.
questions.short_reason: Cultural rules about emotional expression = DISPLAY RULES! Different cultures have different rules for showing emotions. Think: 'Display = Demonstrating emotions differently!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Characteristic institutions are social structures - not emotional expression rules.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Authentic self is your true self - not cultural rules about expression.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Peer groups are social circles - not cultural norms about emotional display.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'display rules.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a dimension of the system for multiple level observation of groups (SYMLOG)?
questions.explanation: SYMLOG is a method for analyzing group dynamics and considers groups along three dimensions: dominant vs. submissive, friendliness vs. unfriendliness, and instrumentally controlled vs. emotionally expressive.
questions.short_reason: SYMLOG has 3 dimensions: Dominance-submission, Friendly-unfriendly, Instrumental-expressive. 'Conformity vs. contrast' isn't one! Think: 'SYMLOG = DFI!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Friendliness vs. unfriendliness IS one of SYMLOG's three dimensions.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Dominance vs. submission IS one of SYMLOG's three dimensions.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Instrumentally controlled vs. emotionally expressive IS one of SYMLOG's three dimensions.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'Conformity vs. contrast' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Political campaign ads often focus on “exposing” an opposing candidate’s negative characteristics. In the dramaturgical approach, one would describe this as:

options.A: bringing the front stage self to the back stage.
options.B: bringing the back stage self to the front stage.

questions.explanation: If a candidate is “exposed,” then personal characteristics that are usually shielded from public view have been brought in front of the public. This would be pulling aspects of the back stage self to the front stage. It would not be considered removing the front stage self, (C), because the candidate still has a public image, even if it has been tarnished.
questions.short_reason: Exposing candidate's private flaws = bringing BACKSTAGE to FRONTSTAGE! Their hidden self becomes public. Think: 'Back to front = Private goes public!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Front to back would be making public self private - opposite of what happens.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Removing front stage would mean no public image at all - but they still have one.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Removing back stage would mean nothing private left - but backstage still exists.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'bringing the back stage self to the front stage.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: In the context of impression management, which of the following selves is most similar to the ought self?
questions.explanation: The ought self is who others think we should be: the expectations imposed by others on us. This is most similar to the tactical self, which is the self we present to others when we adhere to their expectations. The presented self, (D), is a combination of the authentic, ideal, and tactical selves.
questions.short_reason: Ought self (others' expectations) is most like TACTICAL self! Both involve conforming to what others want. Think: 'Tactical = Tailoring to expectations!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Ideal self is who YOU want to be - not others' expectations.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Authentic self is your true self - opposite of performing for others.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Presented self combines all three (ideal, tactical, authentic) - not just ought self.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'The tactical self' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The evolutionary role of emotions has been used as support for which model(s) of emotional expression?

options.C: Both the basic model and social construction model
options.D: Neither the basic model nor the social construction model

questions.explanation: The basic model of emotion, as proposed by Charles Darwin, states that emotions serve an evolutionary purpose and thus are similar across cultures. The seven universal emotions have also been used as support for this theory. The social construction model states that emotions are always a product of the current social situation and does not posit any biological basis for emotions, implying a lack of a role for emotions in evolution.
questions.short_reason: Evolution supports BASIC model only! Basic model says emotions evolved universally. Social construction says emotions are culturally created - no evolution. Think: 'Basic = Biological/evolutionary!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Social construction model explicitly REJECTS biological/evolutionary basis for emotions.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Only basic model uses evolutionary support - not both.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Basic model definitely uses evolutionary support - it's not 'neither.'

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'The basic model only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of intraspecific animal communication?

options.A: A dog who barks when a stranger enters the house
options.B: An anglerfish that uses a bioluminescent appendage to attract prey
options.C: Bats using echolocation to detect the surrounding environment
options.D: A cat who uses scent glands to mark his territory for other cats

questions.explanation: Intraspecific communication refers to communication between members of the same species. Interspecific communication, on the other hand, refers to communication between members of different species. Echolocation, (C), is not an example of intraspecific communication because the sender of the signal and the recipient are the same organism; this would be considered autocommunication.
questions.short_reason: Cat marking territory for OTHER CATS = INTRASPECIFIC (within species) communication! Same species to same species. Think: 'Intra = Inside the species!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Dog barking at stranger is interspecific (different species) communication.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Anglerfish attracting prey is interspecific - predator to prey of different species.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Echolocation is autocommunication - same individual sends and receives (not between individuals).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'A cat who uses scent glands to mark his territory for other cats' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Primary groups differ from secondary groups in that:

options.A: primary groups are shorter-lived than secondary groups.
options.B: primary groups are larger than secondary groups.
options.C: primary groups are formed of stronger bonds than secondary groups.
options.D: primary groups are assigned while secondary groups are chosen.

questions.explanation: Primary groups have direct and close bonds between members, providing warm, personal, and intimate relationships to its members. Secondary groups, in contrast, form superficial bonds and tend to last for a shorter period of time.
questions.short_reason: PRIMARY groups = STRONG, close bonds (family, close friends). Secondary = weaker, more impersonal. Think: 'Primary = Profound bonds!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Primary groups are typically LONGER-lived - relationships endure over time.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Primary groups are SMALLER - intimate bonds don't work with large numbers.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Both can be chosen or assigned - family is assigned but close friends are chosen.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Interaction: Explain why 'primary groups are formed of stronger bonds than secondary groups.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The tendency to become close friends with neighbors rather than people in other neighborhoods is most strongly related to which of the following factors?
questions.explanation: Each of the answer choices influences social attraction; however, proximity deals with the tendency to be attracted to those who are physically close by.
questions.short_reason: Close = friends! PROXIMITY is the strongest predictor - we befriend those physically near us. Think: 'Proximity = Close in place, close in friendship!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Reciprocity is mutual liking - important but not about physical closeness.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Self-disclosure builds intimacy - but proximity gets you together first.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Similarity helps maintain friendships - but proximity initiates them.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'Proximity' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following would be associated with high levels of aggression?
I. Increased amygdala activity
II. Decreased amygdala activity
III. Increased prefrontal cortex activity
IV. Decreased prefrontal cortex activity
questions.explanation: Aggression is influenced both by the amygdala and prefrontal cortex activity. Activity of the amygdala increases aggression. The prefrontal cortex should control aggression; decreased activity in the prefrontal cortex, therefore, is associated with increased aggression.
questions.short_reason: Aggression = HIGH amygdala + LOW prefrontal cortex! Amygdala drives it, prefrontal cortex controls it. Think: 'Amygdala = Anger, Prefrontal = Police!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Increased prefrontal activity would DECREASE aggression - it provides control.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Decreased amygdala would decrease aggression - less emotional reactivity.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: This combination would decrease aggression - less drive, more control.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'I and IV only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A child who cries when a caregiver departs and smiles and runs to the caregiver upon return is displaying which type of attachment pattern?
questions.explanation: This attachment pattern is representative of secure attachment. Secure attachment is seen when a child has a consistent caregiver and is able to go out and explore, knowing there is a secure base to return to. The child will be upset at the departure of the caregiver and will be comforted and resume exploring upon the return of the caregiver.
questions.short_reason: Sad when parent leaves, happy when they return = SECURE attachment! Healthy attachment pattern shows appropriate distress and joy. Think: 'Secure = Sensible reactions!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Avoidant attachment shows little reaction to parent leaving or returning.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Ambivalent shows distress but isn't easily comforted on return.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Disorganized shows confused, contradictory behaviors - no clear pattern.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'Secure attachment' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Elephant seal males mate with multiple females each mating season, while females only have one mate each. What type of mating system is this?
questions.explanation: Polygamy involves having exclusive relationships with several partners, several females (polygyny), or several males (polyandry), (A). Monogamy, (C), consists of exclusive mating relationships. Promiscuity, (D), refers to mating with others without exclusivity.
questions.short_reason: Male with multiple females = POLYGYNY! Poly (many) + gyn (female). Think: 'Polygyny = Guy with many gals!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Polyandry is one female with multiple males - opposite pattern.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Monogamy is one partner for both sexes - not what's described.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Promiscuity lacks exclusive relationships - these are exclusive to the male.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'Polygyny' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A person with a ventromedial hypothalamus injury will likely show which behavior?
questions.explanation: A person with a ventromedial hypothalamus injury will never feel satiated when eating and will therefore never feel the sensation to stop eating. A person with a lateral hypothalamus injury will never feel hunger and will have decreased food intake, (D).
questions.short_reason: VENTROMEDIAL hypothalamus = satiety center. Damage it = never feel full = eat constantly! Think: 'Ventromedial = Very full (normally)!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Empathy isn't related to ventromedial hypothalamus function.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Empathy isn't related to this brain region.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Decreased eating would come from LATERAL hypothalamus damage (hunger center).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'Increased food intake' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Female great reed warblers are attracted to males with larger song repertoires because they tend to produce offspring with higher viability. This is an example of which of the following?
questions.explanation: Phenotypic benefits refer to observed traits in an individual that make them more attractive to other members of their species. Benefits associated with increased fitness through direct material advantages are direct benefits, (C), while indirect benefits involve increased genetic fitness for offspring.
questions.short_reason: Song variety = healthier offspring = INDIRECT phenotypic benefits! Not direct resources, but genetic quality for babies. Think: 'Indirect = Investment in offspring genes!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Runaway selection is when a trait becomes exaggerated just because it's preferred.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Sensory bias is preference based on pre-existing sensory capabilities.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Direct benefits would be resources, territory, or protection - not offspring quality.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'Indirect phenotypic benefits' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: In several species of shrimp, the larger adults will sacrifice themselves to protect the younger, smaller shrimp. How is this behavior best explained?
questions.explanation: In evolutionary psychology, inclusive fitness is a measure of the number of offspring an individual has, how they support their offspring, and how their offspring can support others. Inclusive fitness promotes the idea that altruistic behavior can improve the fitness and success of a species; the behavior in this scenario can be described as altruism: benefiting another at one’s own expense.
questions.short_reason: Adults sacrificing for young = INCLUSIVE FITNESS! Protecting genes by protecting relatives. Think: 'Inclusive = Include your relatives' survival!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Direct benefits are personal gains - this is sacrificing for others.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Sensory bias is about mate attraction preferences - not self-sacrifice.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Foraging is food-seeking behavior - not about self-sacrifice for others.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'Inclusive fitness' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a component of social perception?
questions.explanation: There are three primary components of perception: the perceiver, the target, and the situation.
questions.short_reason: Three components of social perception: PERCEIVER, TARGET, SITUATION. No 'process' - that's HOW perception works, not a component. Think: 'PTS = Person, Target, Setting!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Target IS one of the three components - who/what is being perceived.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Situation IS one of the three components - the context of perception.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Perceiver IS one of the three components - who is doing the perceiving.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'The process' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: When you first meet Dustin, he is very rude to you. You run into him twice more and he is very friendly, but you still dislike him because of your first meeting. What impression bias does this describe?
questions.explanation: The impressions we form when meeting others are influenced by a number of perceptual biases. The primacy effect refers to those occasions when first impressions are more important than subsequent impressions.
questions.short_reason: First impression stuck despite later friendliness = PRIMACY effect! First info weighs more heavily. Think: 'Primacy = Primary impression persists!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Recency effect would favor the LATER (friendly) impressions.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Central traits are key characteristics that color other judgments - not about timing.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Proximity is about physical closeness increasing attraction - not about impression timing.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'Primacy effect' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Mei brings cookies to work. Although you have not yet tasted them, you say to another coworker, “Mei is such a great person; I’m sure these cookies are fantastic!” What type of bias is this?
questions.explanation: The halo effect is a cognitive bias in which judgments of an individual’s character can be affected by the overall impression of the individual.
questions.short_reason: Mei is great so her cookies must be great = HALO EFFECT! One positive trait colors everything else. Think: 'Halo = Her goodness glows onto everything!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Central traits are specific characteristics that influence impressions - not one trait coloring all.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Direct benefits is about mate selection - not about judging cookies.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Similarity is about attraction to similar others - not about assuming quality.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'Halo effect' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A friend wins a tennis game and says, “I trained so hard—that was a great win!” After losing a subsequent match, the friend says, “My baby brother kept me up all night crying; I was tired for the match.” These statements reflect which of the following principles?
questions.explanation: Self-serving bias refers to the fact that individuals will view their own successes as being based on internal factors, while viewing their failures as being based on external factors.
questions.short_reason: I won = my skill. I lost = outside factors. = SELF-SERVING BIAS! We take credit for success, blame failure on circumstances. Think: 'Self-serving = Success is mine, failure is not!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Just-world hypothesis is believing people get what they deserve.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Fundamental attribution error is about judging OTHERS - not ourselves.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Esteem bias isn't a standard term - self-serving bias is correct.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'Self-serving bias' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Carlos is always happy and smiling. Today, you notice he seems down and think something must have happened to upset him. What types of attribution are you making?
I. Internal
II. External
III. Situational
IV. Dispositional
questions.explanation: Types of attribution fall into two main categories: dispositional (internal) and situational (external). Dispositional (internal) causes are related to the features of the person whose behavior is being considered. Situational (external) causes are related to features of the surroundings.
questions.short_reason: Something must have HAPPENED to upset him = EXTERNAL/SITUATIONAL attribution! Blaming the environment, not his personality. Think: 'External = Environment caused it!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Internal/situational is contradictory - internal and situational are opposites.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Internal/dispositional would mean his personality changed - not what we're assuming.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: External/dispositional is contradictory - dispositional means personality (internal).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'II and III only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A group of men and women are going to be rated on their driving abilities. The role of gender is emphasized in the experiment and the women perform worse than the men. In another experiment, the role of gender is not mentioned and the ratings are comparable between the two groups. Which principle do these results support?
questions.explanation: Stereotype threat refers to the phenomenon of people being concerned or anxious about confirming a negative stereotype of their social group. Stereotype threat can hinder performance, creating a self-fulfilling prophecy.
questions.short_reason: Emphasizing gender made women perform worse = STEREOTYPE THREAT! Awareness of negative stereotypes hurts performance. Think: 'Stereotype threat = Stress from stereotypes!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Institutional discrimination is systemic barriers - not individual performance anxiety.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Prejudice is negative attitudes - the mechanism here is about self-consciousness.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Just-world hypothesis is about deservingness - not stereotype effects on performance.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'Stereotype threat' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: The behavior that accompanies the negative attitudes a person has toward a group or individual is referred to as:
questions.explanation: Discrimination is when prejudicial attitudes cause individuals of a particular group to be treated differently than others. While prejudice is an attitude, discrimination is a behavior.
questions.short_reason: BEHAVIOR based on negative attitudes = DISCRIMINATION! Prejudice is the attitude, discrimination is the action. Think: 'Discrimination = Doing something based on prejudice!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Stereotyping is cognitive categorization - beliefs, not behaviors.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Cultural relativism is judging cultures by their own standards - not about negative treatment.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Prejudice is the negative ATTITUDE - discrimination is the resulting BEHAVIOR.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'discrimination.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Game theory is designed to study:
questions.explanation: Game theory was originally designed to study decision-making behavior in economics and mathematics; it has since been used to describe decision making in politics, biology, philosophy, and other fields.
questions.short_reason: GAME THEORY = studying DECISIONS in strategic situations! From economics to biology, it's about rational choices. Think: 'Game theory = Gauging decisions!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Central traits are about impression formation - not strategic decision-making.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Behavior attribution is about explaining causes of behavior - not decision strategies.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Self-enhancement is about maintaining positive self-image - not decision modeling.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Thinking: Explain why 'decision-making behavior.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes a manifest function?

options.A: An intended positive effect on a system
options.B: An intended negative effect on a system
options.C: An unintended positive effect on a system
options.D: An unintended negative effect on a system

questions.explanation: A manifest function is an intended positive effect on a system. A latent function is an unintended positive effect on a system, (C). A negative effect on a system, (B) and (D), is termed a dysfunction.
questions.short_reason: MANIFEST = intended POSITIVE effect! It's what the function is MEANT to do. Think: 'Manifest = Meant to happen!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Intended negative effect would be a dysfunction by design - rare and problematic.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Unintended positive effect = LATENT function - happy accident.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Unintended negative effect = LATENT DYSFUNCTION - unplanned harm.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'An intended positive effect on a system' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Studying why a nod means “yes” in many cultures is most representative of which of the following sociological concepts?
questions.explanation: Symbolic interactionism studies how individuals interact through a shared understanding of words, gestures, and other symbols. A nod is thus a symbol in many cultures that signifies “yes.”
questions.short_reason: Why does a nod mean 'yes'? = SYMBOLIC INTERACTIONISM! Studying shared meanings of gestures and symbols. Think: 'Symbolic = Symbols and their meanings!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Demographic transition is about birth/death rate changes over time.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Expectancy theory is about motivation - expecting effort leads to reward.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Demographic shift is population change - not about gesture meanings.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'Symbolic interactionism' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following ethical principles states that physicians should avoid using treatments with greater potential for harm than benefit?
questions.explanation: The principle of nonmaleficence states that physicians must not only act in their patient’s best interest (beneficence, (B)), but must also avoid treatments where the potential for harm outweighs the potential for benefit.
questions.short_reason: Don't use harmful treatments = NONMALEFICENCE! 'First, do no harm.' Think: 'Nonmaleficence = No harm!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Autonomy is respecting patient's right to make decisions.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Beneficence is actively doing good - beyond just avoiding harm.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Justice is fair distribution of resources and treatment.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'Nonmaleficence' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
A Cuban-American man living in the United States has the dominant physical features of a Black man. He speaks Spanish, prefers Latin foods, and listens to Latin music. His preferences are best defined through which of the following attributes?
I. Race
II. Ethnicity
III. Culture
questions.explanation: Although one’s dominant physical features are associated with race, this man’s preferences are those of Latino ethnicity and culture. Ethnicity is a social construct that considers language, religion, nationality, and cultural factors. Culture relates to a group’s way of life; the preferences listed in the question are examples of material and symbolic culture.
questions.short_reason: Language, food, music preferences = ETHNICITY and CULTURE, not race! Race is physical features; ethnicity/culture are about heritage and practices. Think: 'Ethnicity = Ethnic practices, Culture = Customs!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Race describes physical features - preferences are about culture/ethnicity.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Ethnicity alone is incomplete - culture also describes these preferences.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Race is about physical features - preferences don't determine race.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'II and III only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A patient who resides in the United States says, “I love you,” and hugs the doctor after every routine visit. This behavior violates:
questions.explanation: In the United States, it is not a common practice to say, “I love you,” and hug one’s physician after each routine checkup; therefore, this behavior could be considered deviant, going against the social norm. Values, (C), are what an individual deems to be important.
questions.short_reason: Hugging doctor isn't typical in US = violates SOCIAL NORMS! Norms are expected behaviors in a culture. Think: 'Norms = Normal expectations!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Personal beliefs are individual - this is about societal expectations.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Patient autonomy is about making medical decisions - not about hugging.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Social values are what's considered important - norms are specific behavioral expectations.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'social norms.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following demographics can be measured in events per 1000 people per year?
I. Birth rate
II. Fertility rate
III. Mortality rate
questions.explanation: Both birth rate and mortality rate can be measured per 1000 people per year. Fertility rate is measured in number of children per woman over a lifetime.
questions.short_reason: Birth rate AND mortality rate can be 'per 1000/year.' Fertility rate is 'children per woman per lifetime.' Think: 'Birth & death = per thousand, Fertility = per female lifetime!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Birth rate alone is incomplete - mortality rate also uses this measure.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Fertility rate uses children per woman - it's statement II that's wrong.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Fertility rate (II) uses a different measurement - children per woman, not per 1000.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'I and III only' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Because there are more than 500 American Indian tribes, there are several different healing practices among them. Some tribes may have ceremonies that include chanting, singing, body painting, dancing, and even use of mind-altering substances to persuade the spirits to heal the sick person. These ceremonies are examples of:
questions.explanation: Rituals are formalized ceremonial behaviors in which members of a group or community regularly engage. Therefore, these activities are examples of rituals performed for healing.
questions.short_reason: Ceremonies for healing (chanting, dancing) = RITUALS! Formalized cultural practices with shared meaning. Think: 'Rituals = Repeated cultural practices!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Latent functions are unintended positive effects - healing ceremonies are intentional.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Cultural barriers prevent healthcare access - these ceremonies ARE healthcare in their culture.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Social movements aim to change society - rituals maintain tradition.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'rituals.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Over the last few decades, the United States population has become:
questions.explanation: With a decrease in mortality rate and a higher immigration rate than emigration rate, the United States population continues to grow, with an increasing average age and increasing racial and ethnic diversity.
questions.short_reason: US population is BIGGER (low mortality, immigration), OLDER (baby boomers aging), and MORE DIVERSE (immigration). Think: 'BOD = Bigger, Older, Diverse!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Population is getting OLDER, not younger - baby boomers are aging.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Population is growing, not shrinking - and more diverse, not less.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Population is growing, not shrinking.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'bigger, older, and more diverse.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT an example of material culture?
questions.explanation: Material culture includes any cultural artifact—an object to which meaning is assigned. Values are ideas, which are associated with symbolic culture.
questions.short_reason: Values are IDEAS = SYMBOLIC culture! Material culture is physical objects. Clothing, food, art = material; values = symbolic. Think: 'Material = Matter, Symbolic = Concepts!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Traditional clothing is a physical artifact = material culture.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Cuisine (food) is a physical artifact = material culture.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Sand paintings are physical artifacts = material culture.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'American values' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: During which stage of demographic transition are both birth rates and mortality rates low?
questions.explanation: During demographic transition, both birth rates and mortality rates are high in stage 1, (A). Mortality rates drop during stage 2, (B), and then birth rates drop during stage 3, (C). In stage 4, both birth rates and mortality rates are low.
questions.short_reason: Stage 4 = LOW birth + LOW death rates! Both have dropped after modernization. Think: 'Stage 4 = Stable low rates!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Stage 1 has HIGH birth and HIGH death rates - preindustrial.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Stage 2 has HIGH birth but death starts DROPPING.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Stage 3 has DROPPING birth rates, already low death rates.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'Stage 4' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text:
Shortly after a state legalizes gambling in casinos, a formal coalition forms to oppose the building of any casinos in the major cities of the state. This scenario includes:
I. conflict theory.
II. social institutions.
III. a social movement.
questions.explanation: In this scenario, a group is fighting for social power, which is an aspect of conflict theory. Further, this group is an example of a reactive social movement because it is running counter to social change. The fact that gambling had been legalized implies the involvement of the government, a social institution.
questions.short_reason: Fighting against gambling legalization = CONFLICT THEORY + SOCIAL MOVEMENT + involves GOVERNMENT (institution). All three! Think: 'Power struggle + organized resistance + institutional involvement!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Conflict theory alone is incomplete - social movement and institution are also present.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Missing that social institutions (government) are involved in legalizing gambling.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Missing that this IS conflict theory - groups competing for power/influence.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'I, II, and III' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A young adult male claims to have had sexual relationships mostly with other men, although he has been attracted to women at times. What would be his most likely score on the Kinsey scale?
questions.explanation: This man is describing his sexuality as mostly homosexual, although he has also had some heterosexual attractions. The Kinsey scale scores a 6, (D), as exclusively homosexual. A score of 3 would equate to bisexuality. Thus, this man would likely score a 4 or 5.
questions.short_reason: Mostly homosexual but some heterosexual attraction = Kinsey 5! (6 = exclusively homosexual, 3 = bisexual). Think: 'Kinsey 5 = Strongly one way with some flexibility!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: 0 is exclusively heterosexual - opposite of what's described.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: 1 is predominantly heterosexual - opposite of what's described.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 6 is exclusively homosexual - but he has had some heterosexual attractions.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why '5' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following demographic variables is known to be biologically determined?
questions.explanation: Sex is determined by one’s genotype, and therefore is biologically determined. Gender, (A), may or may not match biological sex and therefore is not biologically determined. Ethnicity, (C), is a social construct that sorts people by cultural factors, and therefore is not biologically determined. Sexual orientation, (D), may have some biological component, but the relative role of biology and environment is not yet known.
questions.short_reason: SEX is biologically determined by chromosomes (XX/XY)! Gender, ethnicity, and orientation have social/environmental components. Think: 'Sex = Set by genes!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Gender is socially constructed - can differ from biological sex.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Ethnicity is a social construct based on cultural factors.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Sexual orientation's origins are debated - not purely biological.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'Sex' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following would contribute to increasing population growth over time?

options.B: An immigration rate larger than emigration rate

questions.explanation: If the immigration rate in a geographic area is larger than the emigration rate, then there is a larger influx than efflux of people. This will increase the population of that area.
questions.short_reason: Immigration > emigration = population GROWS! More coming in than going out. Think: 'More in than out = Growth!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Fertility rate less than 2 would mean each woman has <2 children - population decline.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Increased mortality rate means more deaths - population decline.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Decreased birth rate means fewer babies - population decline.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'An immigration rate larger than emigration rate' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Urbanization can cause all of the following negative effects EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Urbanization is the migration of people into urban centers to create cities. The increased population density should provide additional opportunities for social interaction, not decreased opportunities.
questions.short_reason: Urbanization INCREASES social interaction - more people packed together! It also brings disease, pollution, and crime. Think: 'Cities = Crowded + Connected!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Increased disease transmission IS a negative effect - crowding spreads infection.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Decreased air quality/sanitation IS a negative effect of urbanization.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Increased violent crime IS a negative effect in many urban areas.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Structure and Demographics: Explain why 'decreased opportunity for social interaction.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes the component of socioeconomic status attributable to direct individual efforts?
questions.explanation: Social stratification based on direct efforts, such as merit, is a form of achieved socioeconomic status. Ascribed socioeconomic status, (A), is based on identifiable external characteristics. Achieved status may be due to meritocratic competition, (B), but other individual efforts can also be associated with achieved status. Anomic conditions, (C), are those that cause a breakdown between the individual and society and erode social solidarity.
questions.short_reason: Individual EFFORT = ACHIEVED status! You earn it through merit and work. Think: 'Achieved = Accomplished through Action!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Ascribed status is given at birth - race, gender, family background.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Meritocratic competition is ONE way to achieve status, but not the only definition.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Anomic conditions are breakdown of social norms - unrelated to status achievement.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'Achieved status' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following displays a correct association?

options.A: High social networking and low social capital
options.B: High social mobility and low social capital
options.C: Low social class and low social capital
options.D: Low social networking and high social capital

questions.explanation: Low social class may lead to low social capital. Members of the lower class often have smaller numbers of weak ties in social networks, and therefore have less opportunity to invest in society and reap its benefits.
questions.short_reason: LOW social class = LOW social capital! Fewer connections = fewer opportunities and resources. Think: 'Low class = Low connections!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: High networking would typically lead to HIGH social capital, not low.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: High mobility and low capital don't directly correlate - mobility comes from capital.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Low networking would lead to LOW social capital, not high.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'Low social class and low social capital' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following phenomena are LEAST likely to coincide?

options.A: Hazardous waste facilities and low-income neighborhoods
options.C: Environmental pollution and populations of underrepresented groups

questions.explanation: Globalization does not typically lead to global equality; rather, globalization tends to create further global inequalities. In regard to environmental justice, higher numbers of hazardous waste facilities tend to be found in low-income neighborhoods, (A). Poor living conditions tend to be associated with greater health problems, including tuberculosis, (B). Finally, environmental pollution is more prevalent in areas with larger populations of underrepresented groups, especially when low-income, (C).
questions.short_reason: Globalization creates INEQUALITY, not equality! Rich get richer, gaps widen. Think: 'Globalization = Greater gaps!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Hazardous waste facilities ARE more common in low-income areas - environmental injustice.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: TB and poor living conditions DO coincide - poverty increases disease.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Pollution IS more common in underrepresented communities - environmental injustice.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'Globalization and global equality' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following trends is most likely FALSE?

options.A: Mortality rates are increased in groups with low income.
options.B: Life expectancy is decreased in groups with high income.
options.C: Birth weights are decreased in children of low-income women.
options.D: Rates of lung cancer are increased in low-income groups.

questions.explanation: Groups with high income tend to have increased life expectancy rates, not decreased. People with low income have higher mortality rates than those with high income, (A). Low-income women tend to have children with lower birth weights, (C). Finally, rates of various diseases, including lung cancer, are increased among low-income groups, (D).
questions.short_reason: High income = HIGHER life expectancy, not lower! Wealth buys better health. Think: 'More money = More years!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Low income DOES correlate with higher mortality - this is true.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Low-income mothers DO have lower birth weight babies - this is true.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Low-income groups DO have higher cancer rates - this is true.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'Life expectancy is decreased in groups with high income.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the prevalence of prostate cancer in the population that can develop the condition at the end of the year?
questions.explanation: Prevalence is defined as the total number of cases divided by the possibly affected population during a period of time. Here, the period of time is defined as one point: the end of the year. At the end of the year, there are 30 total cases in a population of 1000 individuals, but only 500 of those individuals can develop prostate cancer, meaning the prevalence is 30 ÷ 500.
questions.short_reason: Prevalence = all current cases / at-risk population. 30 cases in 500 males (only they can get prostate cancer). Think: 'Prevalence = Present cases!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: This is incidence formula - new cases over at-risk population without disease.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Using total population (1000) ignores that only males can get prostate cancer.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 20 was the OLD cases; we need total current cases (30 = 20 old + 10 new).

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why '30 ÷ 500' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: What is the incidence of prostate cancer in this population during the year?
questions.explanation: Incidence is defined as the total number of new cases divided by the at-risk population during a period of time. Here, the period of time is one year. There were 10 new cases in this year, and the at-risk population will be only the males who do not already have prostate cancer; the 20 males already diagnosed and the 500 females should not be included in the at-risk population. Therefore, the incidence in this population is 10 ÷ 480.
questions.short_reason: Incidence = NEW cases / at-risk population. 10 new cases / 480 males who didn't already have it. Think: 'Incidence = Incoming new cases!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Using 1000 includes females who can't get prostate cancer.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: 20/500 is prevalence of OLD cases, not incidence of new ones.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: 30 is total cases; we need only NEW cases (10) for incidence.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why '10 ÷ 480' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: A low-income single parent works a part-time job and lives in a small apartment in the city. When the single parent’s children grow up, they take similar jobs and live in similar housing. This is an example of:
questions.explanation: In this scenario, the children remain in the same socioeconomic class as their parent, indicating a lack of social mobility, (A) and (B). Rather, this is an example of social reproduction, in which social inequality, especially poverty, is passed from one generation to the next.
questions.short_reason: Children stay in same class as parent = SOCIAL REPRODUCTION! Inequality passes down generations. Think: 'Reproduction = Repeating class across generations!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Upward mobility would mean children rise to higher class.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Downward mobility would mean children fall to lower class.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Social exclusion is being shut out of opportunities - related but different concept.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'social reproduction.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true with regard to relative poverty?

options.A: Individuals in relative poverty have incomes below the poverty line.
options.B: Individuals in relative poverty exhibit downward social mobility.
options.C: Individuals in relative poverty may be in the upper class.
options.D: Individuals in relative poverty exhibit upward social mobility.

questions.explanation: Relative poverty is a comparative term: it describes being poorer than those in the surrounding population. Members of the upper class can live in relative poverty compared to others in their neighborhood if they are not as well-off as their neighbors. Relative poverty is not directly associated with upward or downward social mobility, eliminating (B) and (D); individuals living in relative poverty could exhibit mobility in either direction or no social mobility at all.
questions.short_reason: RELATIVE poverty = poor compared to neighbors! Even rich can be in relative poverty in richer neighborhoods. Think: 'Relative = Relative to surroundings!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Below poverty line is ABSOLUTE poverty - specific dollar threshold.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Downward mobility isn't inherent to relative poverty - just being poorer than neighbors.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Upward mobility isn't inherent to relative poverty.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'Individuals in relative poverty may be in the upper class.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: In comparison to urban centers, suburbs tend to have:

options.A: larger racially and ethnically underrepresented populations.
options.D: higher rates of crime and homicide.

questions.explanation: Suburbs tend to have larger upper- and middle-class populations than urban centers; urban centers tend to have larger low-socioeconomic status populations than suburbs. This is due, in part, to the increased mobility seen in upper- and middle-class populations, which permits their migration into the suburbs.
questions.short_reason: Suburbs have MORE upper/middle class! They moved out of cities. Think: 'Suburbs = Successful moved out!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Urban centers tend to have larger underrepresented populations.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Urban centers tend to have higher poverty rates.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Urban centers tend to have higher crime rates.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'larger upper- and middle-class populations.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following terms refers to the burden or degree of disease associated with a given illness?
questions.explanation: Morbidity refers to the burden of illness, or the severity or degree of illness. Mortality, (B), refers to deaths caused by a given illness. Second sickness, (C), is a term used to describe the exacerbation of health outcomes due to social injustice. Chronicity, (D), refers to the duration of a disease, not its severity or significance for the patient.
questions.short_reason: MORBIDITY = burden of disease (how sick you are). Mortality = death. Think: 'Morbid about illness, Mortal about death!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Mortality is about deaths - rate of dying from illness.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Second sickness is social factors worsening health outcomes.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Chronicity is about duration of illness - how long it lasts.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'Morbidity' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Compared to White Americans, which of the following racial or ethnic groups tends to have a better overall health profile?
questions.explanation: In comparison to White Americans, Asian Americans tend to have better overall health profiles. African Americans, (A), tend to have worse overall health profiles. Hispanic Americans and American Indians, (C) and (D), both have mixed health profiles in comparison to White Americans: they are better off in some categories and worse off in others. However, Hispanic Americans and American Indians do not have better overall health profiles than White Americans.
questions.short_reason: ASIAN Americans have BETTER health profiles than White Americans on most measures. Think: 'Asian Americans = Above average health!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: African Americans tend to have worse health profiles on most measures.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Hispanic Americans have mixed results - better on some, worse on others.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: American Indians have mixed results - not consistently better overall.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'Asian Americans' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes the populations targeted by Medicare and Medicaid, respectively?

options.A: Medicare: mostly patients without employer-guaranteed healthcare; Medicaid: mostly patients who have recently immigrated
options.B: Medicare: mostly patients who have recently immigrated; Medicaid: mostly patients without employer-guaranteed healthcare
options.C: Medicare: mostly patients in older age groups; Medicaid: mostly patients with low socioeconomic status
options.D: Medicare: mostly patients with low socioeconomic status; Medicaid: mostly patients in older age groups

questions.explanation: Medicare covers patients over the age of 65 (older age groups), those with end-stage renal disease, and those with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Medicaid covers patients below a certain socioeconomic level.
questions.short_reason: MEDICARE = Elderly (65+). MEDICAID = Low income. Think: 'MediCARE = Care for seniors, MedicAID = Aid for low income!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Neither program specifically targets immigrants or those without employer insurance.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: This reverses the populations - Medicare isn't for immigrants.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: This reverses Medicare and Medicaid populations.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'Medicare: mostly patients in older age groups; Medicaid: mostly patients with low socioeconomic status' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Morbidity is increased in low-income groups because of all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Morbidity refers to the burden or severity of disease. All of the factors listed are true with regard to low-socioeconomic status populations; however, high homicide rates cause increases in mortality, not morbidity.
questions.short_reason: Homicide increases MORTALITY (death rate), not MORBIDITY (illness burden). Dead people don't have illness burden. Think: 'Homicide = Mortality matter!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Obesity DOES increase morbidity - causes many chronic diseases.
wrong_answer_explanations.B: Less healthcare access DOES increase morbidity - diseases go untreated.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: Less physical activity DOES increase morbidity - leads to health problems.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'higher rates of homicide.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Hypertension (high blood pressure) can be diagnosed by having two or more blood pressure readings higher than 140/90 on two different occasions, separated by a week. Suppose that the criteria were changed to include anyone with a reading higher than 130/80 on at least one occasion. How would this change the prevalence of diagnosed hypertension in the population?

options.C: The prevalence would remain the same.
options.D: There is not enough information to determine the change in prevalence.

questions.explanation: If the threshold for hypertension (high blood pressure) were lowered, more individuals would be fit the criteria for the disease. If the number of individuals with the disease increases and the population stays the same overall, there will be an increased prevalence of the disease.
questions.short_reason: Lower diagnostic threshold = MORE people diagnosed = HIGHER prevalence! More cases detected. Think: 'Lower bar = More diagnoses!'

wrong_answer_explanations.B: Lower threshold catches MORE cases, not fewer - prevalence increases.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Changing criteria definitely changes prevalence numbers.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: We have enough information - more inclusive criteria = more cases.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'The prevalence would increase.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.

questions.question_text: Which of the following trends regarding healthcare disparities has NOT been documented?

options.A: Females are more likely to be insured than males.
options.B: Primary care use is more likely among males than females.
options.C: Low-income individuals have more difficulty accessing care than high-income individuals.
options.D: LGBTQ individuals have more barriers to healthcare than other individuals.

questions.explanation: In comparison to females, males visit primary care doctors less frequently. All of the other trends listed here have been documented.
questions.short_reason: Males visit primary care LESS than females, not more! Men avoid doctors more. Think: 'Men = Macho about medical visits!'

wrong_answer_explanations.A: Females being more insured IS a documented trend.
wrong_answer_explanations.C: Low-income difficulty accessing care IS documented.
wrong_answer_explanations.D: LGBTQ healthcare barriers ARE documented disparities.

learn_with_ai.prompt: MCAT Behavioral Sciences - Social Stratification: Explain why 'Primary care use is more likely among males than females.' is correct. Include a simple explanation, why students get this wrong, and a memory trick.
